conversation.content: [joking] Please tell me you're not the one who signed up for the extreme rapids with zero experience.

[empathetically] That would be me, actually. I know it sounds insane but my therapist said I needed to stop living in my head and start feeling things in my body—apparently near-death experiences count.
Your therapist told you to go white water rafting?
She said to "embrace physical challenges that force presence." I figured class four rapids would definitely force me to be present, assuming I don't get swept downstream first.
[warm] Well, you picked the right guide. I've run this river maybe three hundred times.
Three hundred times on the same river? Don't you get bored seeing the same rocks and turns over and over again?
It's never the same river twice. Water levels change everything.
That's either deeply philosophical or you're trying to make me feel better about my impending doom. Either way, I appreciate the effort—my ex-husband would've just laughed at me.
[child-like] Wait, is that why you're here? Post-divorce adventure phase?
Post-divorce, post-career-change, post-everything phase. Sold my dental practice, bought an RV, and decided to do everything that terrified me for a year.
You were a dentist?
Orthodontist for fifteen years. Spent my days staring into teenagers' mouths and pretending their parents weren't insane—turns out I was the insane one for choosing that life.
What else is on your terror list?
Skydiving, done. Standup comedy, bombed spectacularly. Snake handling, which was weirdly therapeutic, and next month I'm doing an ayahuasca ceremony in Peru.
[long pause] You went from braces to ayahuasca. That's... quite a journey.
Life's too short to keep playing it safe. I spent forty-three years being responsible and all it got me was a nice house I never enjoyed and a husband who preferred his secretary.
[very quickly] Oh god, I'm sorry, that's awful.
Don't be sorry—she did me a favor. If Jennifer from accounting hadn't sent those photos to the wrong phone, I'd still be living my beige little life in suburban Connecticut.
And instead you're about to hit class four rapids with a complete stranger.
A complete stranger who's done this three hundred times. Besides, the best things in my life have happened when I trusted strangers—that's how I learned I could survive anything.
